thread.title: Aussie natural wonder tops travel list
thread.title_full: Aussie natural wonder tops travel list

title: Aussie natural wonder tops travel list
text:
A PLANE that was used by top military officials to plot strategy during three wars is in danger of having more than just its wings clipped despite its colourful history and a roster of passengers. Travel Updates Great Barrier Reef rated better than Great Wall of China, Grand Canyon and the Colosseum by: Robyn Ironside National Travel Writer From: Natural beauty ... the Great Barrier Reef has been ranked second on Lonely Planet’s list of the 500 Best Places in the World. Picture: AFP/Sarah Lai Source: AFP UNESCO to monitor Great Barrier Reef progress 1:30 
UNESCO says Australia has a way to go to protect the Great Barrier Reef from an endangered listing. Sky News 02 Jul 2015 News 
QUEENSLAND’S the Great Barrier Reef has been ranked second on Lonely Planet’s list of the 500 Best Places in the World. 
The largest living thing on Earth, the Reef recently avoided being declared “in danger” by the United Nations due to concerns about environmental degradation. 
But Lonely Planet’s Ultimate Travelist ranked the Great Barrier Reef among the world’s must see places, beating the Great Wall of China, the Taj Mahal in India and the Grand Canyon in the US. 
The only place judged more impressive, was Cambodia’s Temples of Angkor. 
“Angkor isn’t just an interesting ruin, it’s a spiritual epiphany in stone,” said Lonely Planet spokesman Chris Zeiher. Spiritual epiphany ... Angkor Wat in Cambodia is the world’s number one must-see destination. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied 
The list was compiled from all the highlights found in every Lonely Planet guidebook over the last 40-years. 
Everyone in the Lonely Planet community was then asked to vote on their top 20 sights, and the list of 500 was created based on those that received the most votes. 
In addition to the Great Barrier Reef, nine other Australian attractions made the Ultimate Travelist. 
The Twelve Apostles off the Great Ocean Road in Victoria was ranked 12th, followed by Hobart’s Museum of Old and New Art (MONA) at number 20. 
Cradle Mountain in Tasmania at 32 was considered marginally more spectacular than Uluru (33) and Kakadu National Park came in at 56. Incredible sight ... Twelve Apostles off the Great Ocean Road in Victoria ranked 12th. Picture: Jarrod Castaing Source: Supplied 
The iconic Sydney Opera House was 57th, the Blue Mountains National Park 202nd, and Ningaloo Marine Park in Western Australia 265th. 
Port Arthur in Tasmania was the final Aussie place to make the list, managing 416th place. 
Mr Zeiher said the Great Barrier Reef was worthy of its ranking as the second best place in the world. 
“This vital ecosystem enthrals all who visit — with abundant bird life and countless tropical islands and beaches,” he said. 
The world’s largest coral reef will be featured in a new Tourism Australia campaign later this year promoting coastal attractions and carrying the slogan “come over to our place for a swim”. 
A new Sir David Attenborough documentary on the Reef is also due to be released early next year to a global audience of more than a billion people in 30 countries. Whale of a time ... the tail of a humpback whale breaks the water in front of the Sydney Opera House in Sydney. Picture: Jonas Liebschner/whalewatchingsydney.com.au via AP Source: AP 
Top Ten Places on Lonely Planet’s Ultimate Travelist 
1. Temples of Angkor, Cambodia 
2. Great Barrier Reef, Australia 
3. Machu Picchu, Peru 
4. Great Wall of China 
5. Taj Mahal, India 
6. Grand Canyon National Park, USA 
7. Colosseum, Italy
